title: 103_s1926
content: The "Food Stamp Program Improvements Act of 1994" may be cited as the short title. The Act includes provisions for budgeting and monthly reporting on reservations. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to allow State agencies to require monthly reporting by households on reservations without delaying or terminating benefits. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to allow State agencies to require monthly reporting by households on reservations, with a certification period of 2 years unless a shorter period is justified. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Act. SEC. 102. STAGGERED ISSUANCES ON RESERVATIONS. Section 7(h)(1) of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to allow for staggered issuance of benefits for eligible households on reservations upon request of the tribal organization. Additionally, a GAO study will be conducted on the administration of the food stamp program by tribal organizations. The Comptroller General will conduct a study to modify requirements and cost-sharing for tribal organizations under the food stamp program. The tribal organization will be allowed to establish their own requirements for issuance, reporting, and certification. A report on the study results is due by December 1, 1994 to specific committees in the House of Representatives. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on modifying requirements and cost-sharing for tribal organizations under the food stamp program. The study results will be considered by relevant committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate during the 1995 reauthorization of the program. SEC. 104. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Repeals Section 908 of the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act Amendments of 1991 and amends Section 6(c)(4) of the Food Stamp Act of 1977. Section 3 of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to define an establishment or house-to-house trade route that sells food for home preparation and consumption. The establishment must offer a variety of foods in each of the 4 categories of staple foods, including perishable foods in at least 2 categories, or have over 50 percent of total sales in staple foods. This determination can be made through various inventory or accounting methods customary in the retail food industry. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to define staple foods as meat, poultry, fish, bread, cereals, vegetables, fruits, and dairy products. Staple foods do not include accessory items like coffee, tea, drinks, candy, condiments, and spices. SEC. 202. PERIODIC NOTICE. SEC. 203. USE AND DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION PROVIDED BY RETAIL FOOD STORES AND WHOLESALE FOOD CONCERNS. Section 9(c) of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to allow disclosure of information to federal and state law enforcement agencies for administering purposes. SEC. 204. DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS TESTING ACTIVITIES DIRECTED AT TRAFFICKING IN COUPONS. Any unauthorized disclosure of information obtained under this subsection may result in a fine or imprisonment. Regulations will establish criteria for determining the need for information. The Secretary will use funds for demonstration projects to combat coupon trafficking by collaborating with law enforcement agencies. SEC. 205. CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY. An establishment or house-to-house trade route authorized to accept and redeem coupons under the Food Stamp Act of 1977 will be considered a retail food store until reauthorization or evaluation of eligibility. SEC. 206. REPORT ON IMPACT ON RETAIL FOOD STORES. The Secretary of Agriculture must submit a report to Congress within 18 months of this Act's enactment on the effects of amendments on retail food stores participating in the food stamp program. This report will include details on newly authorized stores, stores withdrawn from the program, and the eligibility determination procedures used. The report to Congress will assess the eligibility procedures for stores in the food stamp program, the guidance provided to retail food stores, and the impact of the amended definition of "retail food store" on the program's integrity. Speaker of the House of Representatives and Vice President of the United States.
